ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The customers of CSM Bakery Products are both large and small. They look to us for excellent value, dependable delivery, consistent formulas and hands-on service. Since our inception in 1971, our simple goal has been to be the most reliable and responsive company in our industry.  The CSM Bakery Products management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surround communities.  CSM Bakery ProductsA? safety and environmental policies are administered by the Corporate Safety & Risk Manager, who oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program for the anhydrous ammonia systems and the CalARP Program for the aqueous ammonia system.

CSM Bakery Products employees conduct ongoing inspections, testing, and replacement of the critical items in the ammonia refrigeration systems and the aqueous ammonia system.  The aqueous ammonia system is monitored during daily rounds by the Facility Supervisor.   The ammonia refrigeration system is inspected daily by the Facility Coordinator.  A record of the maintenance or work performed on the systems is maintained onsite.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The CSM Bakery Products facility is located at 2111 West Valley Blvd. in Colton, California.  The facility is located approximately 0.1 mile north of the Interstate 10 and approximately 3.1 miles west of Highway 215.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is primarily urban with light commercial and residential areas.  

The ammonia refrigeration processes are used for the chilling and storage of a variety of food products in their processing area and cold storage warehouse.  The refrigeration process, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid,

low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for cold storage rooms and to continuous line blast freezers.  Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature.  For example, lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature.  Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat.  Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize.  Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid.  Typical operating conditions range from 11A? Hg to 30 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 150-180 psig on the high side.

Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the two separate and independent refrigeration processes.  The ammonia inventory in the original system is 19,100 pounds, while the second system (July 2001) contains an ammonia inventory of 22,500 pounds. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Section 5189 of Title 8, CCR), the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  This prevention program covers those processes that handle anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia (29%) above the threshold quantity.

Ammonia Refrigeration System

The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:

A? IIAR Bulletin 107, A?Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-insA?
A? IIAR Bulletin 109, A?Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration SystemA?
A? IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems"
A? IIAR,

A?A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration SystemA?

In addition, CSM Bakery Products has implemented a Process Safety Management program for compliance with the Cal-OSHA regulation.  There are also ammonia detectors located throughout the facility.  There are sensors within Machine Room 1's Freezers, Cooler Dock, Processing Area, and Cooler Room which will alarm at 25 ppm.  The visual and audible alarms are activated at the Freezer Room entrance and a signal is sent to the central computer and is logged within alarm history and will wait for operator response, otherwise, if time occurs, operators are paged.  An initial shutdown occurs at 125 ppm which does the following: (1) Evaporator fans turned off, (2) Evaporator liquid supply and hot gas valves are closed, and (3) Fire department is notified.  There are also ammonia sensors within the Machine Room 1 which will have the following actions at 125 ppm:  (1) Shut down of solenoid valves in order to isolate the ammonia, (2) The purge ventilation fan is turned on with a manual reset required, (3) scrubbing system pumps and fans are turned on with a manual reset required, and (4) Signal is sent to notify operator (refrigeration contractor).  Audible and visual alarms are activated in the Machine Room and a signal is sent ot an auto dialer to alert opreators.  Security Link is instructed to call the fire dpartment.  The exhaust fans are energized and exhaust is routed from the Engine Room to the Condenser inlet then the automatic controls energize the condenser fans and water make-up to scrub the exhaust air.  A final shutdown occurs at 10,000 ppm which de-energizes all of the equipment in the machine room including the compressors.  The facility is equipped with an automatic shut off button located outside of the Machine room.  If a release were to occur, operators can activate this prevention measure.   

Sensors are also located within Machine Room 2 (July 2001).  Sensors in the new Pr

ocessing Area activates the audible and visual alarms in the refrigeration space at 25 ppm and a signal is sent to the auto dialer (Security Link) who contacts operators.  An initial shut down occurs at 125 ppm where all refrigeration valves and evaporators are de-energized. The sensors in the Machine Room will activate the audible and visual alarms in the Machine Room at 25 ppm and a signal is sent to the auto dialer to alert operators.  At 125 ppm, the following actions will take place:  (1) Audible and visual alarms are activated and a signal is sent to an auto dialer to alert operators, (2) Security Link calls the fire department, (3) King valve shut down, (4) Exhaust fans are energized and exhaust is routed from the engine room to the condenser inlet, and (5) The automatic controls energize the condenser fans and water make-up to scrub the exhaust air.  Shutdown occurs at 10,000 ppm which de-energizes all of the equipment in the machine room.  The facility is equipped with three automatic shut off buttons located outside of the Machine Room 2 doors.  If a release were to occur, managers or operators can activate this prevention measure.  

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the facilityA?s accident history showed that there was one release of anhydrous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds over the past five years (June 2005 A? January 2009).  On August 25, 2008, there was an ammonia release through a relief valve located on the roof at 216 psig and the discharge temperature was 178oF for 90 minutes.  Approximately 1,413 pounds of anhydrous ammonia was released into the diffusion tank.  This was due to the burn out of the condenser fan which caused the cooling system to fail and ammonia pressure to rise.  Also, the evaporative condenser spray nozzles and filters were clogged and dirty which inhibited the ventilation system.  The water spray nozzles/distributors are not functioning as designed; therefore, the water is

not being distributed in a uniform pattern over the coils.  Another contributing factor was that the pressure relief valve activated below the setpoint of 250 psig.  In addition, the emergency exhaust fan did not work because the power was cut when the circuit breaker activated by the burn out of the condenser motor.  The ammonia alarm sounded due to a smell of ammonia outside the ammonia room.  All employees at the plant were evacuated and the fire department was automatically notified.  The fire department arrived and assessed the situation.  The fire department ordered all persons to stay out of the plant until they gave the all clear.  CSM Bakery Products later called SCS Tracer Environmental, formerly known as Tracer ES&T, to be part of the incident investigation team.  SCS Tracer Environmental recommended CSM Bakery Products to do the following:

1.    Change the relief valve
2.    Change the electrical source to the emergency exhaust fan
3.    Add other computer access location outside the ammonia room 

The facility has completed the following tasks:  1) replaced the electric fan motor was replaced, 2) cleaned the Evaporative CondensersA? nozzles and filter, 3) changed the electrical wiring so the the electrical source of the emergency exhaust fan system is independent of the evaporative condenser fan motor, and 4) add computer access location outside of the ammonia room.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

CSM Bakery Products has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  In the case of an ammonia-related or an aqueous ammonia related emergency, facility management will determine if an evacuation is necessary.  It is the policy of CSM Bakery Products to evacuate the employees and call 911 in order to reach the San Bernardino County Fire Department HazMat team who will respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel). 

Employees and contractors of CSM Bakery Products are obligated to report any significant releases or po

tential releases of hazardous materials including ammonia and aqueous ammonia.  

The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Response Program section of the PSM/RMP/CalARP (ammonia) and CalARP (aqueous ammonia) documents, which are maintained at the facility and updated as necessary.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

A? save lives
A? minimize and avoid injuries
A? protect the environment
A? minimize property damage
 
The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, aqueous ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations as well as to incorporate facility changes.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Five Year Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study was conducted on September 7, 2006 and August 13, 2007 for System 1 (1999 System) and System 2 (2001 System), respectively.  The Revalidation Teams reviewed the previous procedural/managerial recommendations made during the original PHA, and made additional recommendations to improve safety at the facility.  As part of the 2006 and 2007 Revalidation, a Seismic Assessment Revalidation and a Hazard Assessment (Off-Site Consequence Analysis) Update were completed.  These technical analyses were reviewed and updated to reflect the current status of the CSM Bakery Products facility.

A Three-Year Compliance Audit was performed on June 10, 2010.  This study consolidated all outstanding recommendations from 2007 PHA Revalidation for System 1, 2007 Three-Year Compliance Audit, and 2008 Five Year Mechanical Integrity Inspection.  The study generated recommendations which mostly involve updating documentation to reflect current conditions and formalizing documentation regarding pro

cedures and practices already in place.  

The CSM Bakery Products safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
